Fig. 1 Preparation and performance of a novel graphene-supported palladium complex (rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd) catalyst. Since the palladium complex has a long and flexible C–C chain, the rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd is expected to be an efficient and sustainable S-M catalyst. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Synthetic route of 8 C-TPPO (Y3). Novel graphene-supported palladium complex catalyst with flexible-bridge-chains and its recycling carbon-carbon cross-coupling activity Wenqing Yang a Yuqiang Zhang a Huiyi Feng a Shihao Li a Yi-Si Feng a b ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hefei University of Technology, Hefei 230009, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hefei University of Technology Hefei 230009 China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hefei University of Technology, Hefei 230009, China b Anhui Province Key Laboratory of Advance Catalytic Materials and Reaction Engineering, Hefei 230009, China Anhui Province Key Laboratory of Advance Catalytic Materials and Reaction Engineering Hefei 230009 China Anhui Province Key Laboratory of Advance Catalytic Materials and Reaction Engineering, Hefei 230009, China ⁎ Corresponding author at: School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hefei University of Technology, Hefei 230009, China. School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hefei University of Technology Hefei 230009 China A novel Suzuki-Miyaura (S-M) cross-coupling catalyst (rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd) was prepared by grafting organopalladium complexes with long and flexible chains onto the surface of reduced graphene oxide (rGO) by carbon-carbon covalent bonding. The catalyst was characterized by FTIR, Raman, UV-Vis, TGA, SEM and nitrogen adsorption techniques, respectively. rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd has been used in a variety of S-M coupling reactions. The results showed that it had excellent catalytic activity for various substrates with different substituent groups or substituent positions in ethanol/water mixed solvent at room temperature. Under the optimized reaction conditions, the coupling reaction yield of 4-methyl biphenyl was more than 98 % with iodobenzene and p-tolylbonoric acid as substrates. Even if rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd was recycled for 10 times, the product yield decreased by only 10.4 %, and the chemical structure of the catalyst was basically unchanged. This novel catalytic system provides a new strategy for the design and preparation of supported catalysts. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords RGO-supported catalyst S–M cross-coupling reaction C-C linkage Recyclability Data Availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Palladium-related catalysts can be used in different types of cross-coupling reactions, such as Suzuki-Miyaura [1,2], Heck [3,4], Sonogashira [5,6] reactions, etc. Such coupling reactions, the most reliable and important means for carbon-carbon bond construction in organic syntheses, provide a possible method for the production of active pharmaceutical intermediates [7,8] and new materials [9,10]. However, in practice, most homogeneous palladium complexes are characterized by high cost, high toxicity, and high residue [11,12]. More importantly, it is difficult to completely separate harmful palladium from products, resulting in difficulties in catalyst recovery, which hinders its application in industrial production. Researchers have made a lot of efforts to immobilize the homogeneous catalyst on the solid supports, so that the catalyst can still maintain high catalytic efficiency and easy separation after repeated recycling [13,14]. The catalyst support shall be easily modified to form inorganic, organic, or hybrid materials with excellent specific surface area, high thermal stability, good mechanical stability and the ability to stabilize active materials in an acidic or alkaline environment [15,16]. Moreover, when the catalyst is in the reaction system, the active centers should be in full contact with the substrates, and the size of the substrate molecules should not be limited [17]. For metal related catalysts, ensuring the high dispersion of active components fixed on the support in the solvent and preventing the aggregation of active components after repeated recycling are particularly important for the atomic utilization of heterogeneous catalysts. This is the key to the selection of catalyst support. Quite a few inorganic and organic materials have become candidate support materials, including polymer [18,19], porous silica [20,21], metal oxide [22,23], clay [24,25], carbon material [26,27], porous organic cage [28], and so on. Graphene is a two-dimensional carbon material formed by the tight arrangement of carbon atoms in a hexagonal crystal lattice. Because of its excellent physical and chemical properties [29,30], graphene has been widely used in many fields [31,32]. In particular, graphene has low specific gravity, high specific surface area and good structural stability under various acidic or alkaline conditions, making it an ideal choice for catalyst support [33]. In recent years, using oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface and edge of graphene oxide (GO) to covalently fix the active components on GO to prepare supported catalysts has become a research hotspot [34]. Li [35] reported a novel "tubular" cyclic arylimine, which was covalently grafted on the surface of GO. In an S-M coupling reaction, the microenvironment on the surface of the support experienced a significant change after 7 cycles, and the active metals aggregated, resulting in a decrease in the yield. Bhat [36] reported that the catalyst formed by covalent grafting of cobalt Schiff base on the surface of amino-functionalized GO showed high activity in the cross-coupling reaction of aryl halide and aryl boric acid. It remained stable after 5 cycles of use. Shim [37] reported a practical method for fixing the NHC-Pd complex on the surface of functionalized graphene. The catalyst showed a wide range of substrate adaptability in S-M cross-coupling. Herein, we report a novel rGO-supported palladium complex catalyst (rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd) to create an efficient, sustainable and easy-to-recover S-M catalyst. In our approach, rGO was used as catalyst support, and a new palladium complex (8 C-TPP-Pd) with long and flexible carbon chains was grafted onto the surface of rGO by covalent bonding ( Fig. 1). In this way, we constructed a new and interesting catalyst. At the macroscopic level, rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd can diffuse and float evenly in the solvent with slight stirring, providing a guarantee of homogeneity in the reaction system. Secondly, since 8 C-TPP-Pd have long and flexible carbon chains, the catalytic active centers can move freely within a limited space, resulting in micro-scale uniformity of the catalyst. The rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd is able to achieve catalytic homogeneity at both macroscopic and microscopic scales, greatly increasing the chance of collisions between substrate molecules and activity centers, and thus realizing the expected target of the designed catalyst. The excellent catalytic and recycling performance of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd may provide a practical way for developing the concept of efficient catalysis. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Diphenylphosphine oxide (98 %), 4-iodophenol (98 %), palladium (II) acetate (Pd(OAc)2, 99 %) and reduced graphene oxide (rGO) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Chem. Co. (China). Ethyl acetoacetate (99 %), trichlorosilane (98 %), dioxane (99 %), triethylamine (98 %), DPPF(1,1′-bis(diphenylphosphino)ferrocene) (99 %), TMEDA (N,N,N′,N′-tetramethylethylenediamine), and potassium carbonate (K2CO3, 99 %) were purchased from energy chemical Co. (Shanghai, China). All chemicals were of reagent grade and used as received. Unless otherwise noted, all reactions were performed using Schlenk vacuum-line system under an argon atmosphere. 2.2 Characterization Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded on a ThermoFisher Nicolet iS 50 + FTIR spectrophotometer, scanning 64 times at a spectral resolution of 1 cm−1, using KBr powder at room temperature. Raman spectra were recorded on a ThermoFisher laser confocal micro Raman spectrometer with a 532 nm laser source, scanning for 1 s at 8 mW. Ultraviolet-visible spectra were recorded on a Jasco V-650 spectrometer. 1H NMR (400 MHz) and 13C NMR (100 MHz) were recorded on a Bruker AVANCE III 400 nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometer (NMR). Scanning electronic microscope (SEM) images were taken on a Zeiss Gemini 500 SEM. High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscope (HRTEM) images were taken on JEOL JEM-2100. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted with the Thermo Scientific ESCA Lab 250Xi using 200 W monochromat Al Kα radiation. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a TA Q500 thermogravimetric analyzer at a heating rate of 10 ℃/min. Determination of phosphorus and palladium contents were simultaneously conducted on a Thermofisher ICAP Q inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS). The actual phosphorus and palladium contents were calculated according to the following formula. The results are shown in Table 1. C = C X × V × 10 − 3 A r × W Where, C is the actual phosphorus or palladium content, in mmol/g; C X is the measured phosphorus or palladium content, in ppb (10−9 g/mL); V is the sample volume before determination, 100 mL; A r is the relative atomic weight; phosphorus is 31.0 g/mol and palladium is 106.4 g/mol; W is sample mass, in grams. 2.3 Preparation of homogeneous catalyst ligand 8 C-TPPO (Y3) Homogeneous catalyst ligand 8 C-TPPO (TPPO, triphenylphosphine oxide) was prepared according to the synthetic route shown in Fig. 2 The synthetic methods and NMR characterizations for compounds Y1-Y3 are shown in Supporting Information. 2.4 Synthesis of (4-hydroxyphenyl)diphenylphosphine oxide (Y1) (4-hydroxyphenyl)diphenylphosphine oxide (Y1) was synthesized according to a previously reported procedure [38]. Typically, under an argon atmosphere, p-iodophenol (4.55 mmol), diphenylphosphine oxide (5.45 mmol), 1,1′-bis(diphenylphosphino)ferrocene (DPPF, 90.2 µmol), cesium carbonate (6.82 mmol), Pd(OAc)2 (45.5 µmol) and anhydrous DMF (20 mL) were added to a dried Schlenk flask and stirred at 120 °C for 7 h. After the reaction was complete and cooled to room temperature, the mixture was extracted with CH2Cl2 (30 mL) and washed with saturated ammonium chloride, water and brine, respectively. The organic layer was dried over anhydrous Na2SO4 and evaporated under reduced pressure, then purified via silica gel column by eluting with CH2Cl2/Methanol (50:1) to obtain the target product. (Supporting Information, Fig. S6-S8). 2.7 Preparation of catalyst rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd See Fig. 3. 2.8 Preparation of rGO-8 C-TPPO rGO-8 C-TPPO was prepared according to the procedure shown in Fig. 3. Typically, A mixture of rGO (20 mg) and NMP (50 mL) was sonicated for 1 h. Under an argon atmosphere, Y3 (0.96 mmol), Na2S (2.77 mmol) and isoamyl nitrite (1.17 mmol) were added sequentially in a spherical Schlenk tube. The reaction mixture was stirred under argon at 70 °C for three days, and then the same molar amount of Y3, Na2S and isoamyl nitrite were added. After another three days of reaction, the suspension was filtered through a membrane (0.22 µm), and the solid was washed several times with water, NMP, and dichloromethane, respectively. The filter cake was re-dissolved in NMP and filtered out several times until the mass of the filter cake is constant to obtain a black powder. 2.9 Preparation of catalyst rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd In an argon environment, 20 mg of rGO-8 C-TPPO and 25 mL of THF/toluene (1:1) mixed solvent were added into a 50 mL spherical Schlenk tube and dissolved with ultrasonic assistance for 10 min. After adding trichlorosilane (15 mmol), the reaction system was heated to 110 °C and reacted for 2 h, and then cooled to room temperature. Under the protection of argon, Pd(OAc)2 (5 mg) THF solution was added and stirred at room temperature for 12 h, 10 % sodium hydroxide aqueous solution was added to quench the reaction, then the solvent was removed by high-speed centrifugation (8000 rpm, 20 min), and the product was washed three times with THF and dichloromethane respectively. The product was vacuum dried at 60 °C for 24 h. 2.10 Typical procedure for suzuki-miyaura coupling reaction The as-prepared catalyst rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd was used in several S-M coupling reactions. Typically, 1 mg of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd and 5 mL of 60 % ethanol aqueous solution were added to a round-bottom flask. After stirring the mixture for 5 min, p-tolylbonoric acid ( Table 2, b, 0.50 mmol), K3PO4 (0.58 mmol), and iodobenzene (a1, 0.50 mmol) were sequentially added and stirred at 25 °C for 2 h. After filtering out the catalyst, the mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate. The yield of 4-methyl biphenyl (c1) was determined by HPLC (yield 96 %). The crude product was purified by silica gel chromatography (eluting with hexane) to obtain c1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd Fig. 4 shows the FTIR spectra of rGO, ligand 8 C-TPPO and catalyst rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd. It can be seen from Fig. 4 that rGO has almost no peak on the FTIR spectrum, while the peaks at 3450 cm−1 and 1640 cm−1 are respectively assigned to the O–H stretching and bending vibration of adsorbed water. 8 C-TPPO presents plenty of absorption bands on the FTIR spectrum, such as the C–H stretching vibration of the aromatic ring at 3050 cm−1, the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration bands of methylene groups at 2936 cm−1 and 2856 cm−1, the typical absorption bands of the skeletal vibration of the aromatic ring at 1600 cm−1, 1506 cm−1, 1439 cm−1and 1404 cm−1, the symmetric stretching vibration of the nitro group connected to the benzene ring at 1338 cm−1, the stretching vibration of O–C connected to the benzene ring at 1258 cm−1, the PO stretching vibration at 1180 cm−1, the C–H bending vibration of para-substituted benzene ring at 845 cm−1, as well as the C–H bending vibration of single substituted benzene ring at 754 cm−1 and 706 cm−1. The rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd has a quite similar FTIR spectrum to that of 8 C-TPPO. It also shows various absorption bands at 3050, 2936, 2856, 1600, 1506, 1439, 1258, 1180, 1123, 845, 754 and 706 cm−1 respectively, except that the strong stretching vibration band of the nitro group at 1338 cm−1 disappears, indicating that the nitro group at the end of 8 C-TPPO has been reduced to an amino group in the later stage, and then diazotization addition reaction occurs with rGO, grafting 8 C-TPPO to the surface of rGO. In order to further confirm the structure of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd, the purified samples were characterized by Raman spectroscopy. Fig. 5 shows the Raman spectra of rGO, 8 C-TPPO and rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd. In the Raman spectrum of rGO, the peaks at 1338, 1580 and 2670 cm−1 are ascribed to the unique D-band, G-band and 2D-band of graphene, respectively. The 8 C-TPPO exhibits quite a few Raman scattering peaks, such as =C–H rocking vibration and bending vibration of benzene ring at 848 cm−1 and 990 cm−1 respectively, C–O stretching vibration at 1100 cm−1, PO stretching vibration at 1102 cm−1, Ar–O stretching vibration at 1256 cm−1, NO2 stretching vibration at 1328 cm−1, benzene ring skeleton vibration at 1585 cm−1, C–H asymmetric and symmetrical stretching vibration of CH2 at 2930 cm−1 and 2850 cm−1, as well as the C–H stretching vibration on benzene ring at 3056 cm−1. The Raman spectrum of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd seems to be the superposition of the Raman spectra of rGO and 8 C-TPPO, that is, D-band at 1338 cm−1, G-band at 1580 cm−1 and 2D-band at 2670 cm−1 of rGO appear on the spectrum of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd, and the Raman scattering peaks of 8 C-TPPO also appear at 848, 990, 1338 and 3056 cm−1. But there are some changes. Firstly, the scattering peak of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd becomes stronger at 1585 cm−1, which is due to the overlapping of the G-band of rGO and the scattering peak of benzene skeleton in 8 C-TPPO. Secondly, the peak at 1328 cm−1 almost disappeared, meaning that the end group NO2 of 8 C-TPPO had reacted with rGO after reduction and diazotization. Thirdly, there is no PO peak at 1102 cm−1, accounting for the reduction of PO and the formation of P→Pd. The above analyses confirmed that rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd was successfully prepared. Fig. 6 displays the UV-Vis spectra of rGO, 8 C-TPPO, and rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd. As is seen in Fig. 6, rGO has large absorption in the ultraviolet and visible regions, but there is no obvious absorption peak. 8 C-TPPO has large absorption in the ultraviolet region, but almost no absorption in the visible region and a characteristic absorption peak appears around 316 nm, which is related to the π-π * transition of triphenylphosphorus structure. rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd presents a UV-Vis absorption spectrum similar to that of 8 C-TPPO, with an absorption peak at 316 nm, but the absorption intensity decreased. The results proved again that 8 C-TPPO had been grafted onto the surface of rGO. 3.2 N2 adsorption-desorption characterization of rGO and rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd Fig. 7 shows the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of rGO and rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd. As seen in Fig. 7, rGO and rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd have similar adsorption isotherms and belong to IUPAC type III. The adsorption capacity is small in the low-pressure area. With the increase of relative pressure, the adsorption capacity gradually increases. When it is close to the saturated vapor pressure, the adsorption behavior similar to macropores occurs due to the stacking of layered rGO, and the adsorption isotherm rises rapidly. Comparing the specific surface area (SSA) of the two, the SSA of rGO is very large (1363.2 m2/g), while the SSA of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd is greatly reduced to 320.3 m2/g. The reason is that after grafting a large number of organic ligands on the surface of rGO, the organic ligands occupy the surface of rGO and embed into the gaps formed by the accumulation of flake rGO, resulting in a significant reduction of SSA. It was confirmed again that the grafting of organic ligands on the surface of rGO was successful. 3.3 Loading Amount of Graphene-supported Catalyst rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd Fig. 8 shows the thermogravimetric (TG) curves of rGO, 8 C-TPPO and rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd. As seen in Fig. 8, the thermal weight loss behavior of the three samples is obviously different in the nitrogen atmosphere. The weight loss of rGO is not obvious, and the weight loss is only 3.33 % at 600 ℃, showing good thermal stability. Ligand 8 C-TPPO begins to lose weight for the first time at about 260 ℃, which may be related to the breaking and decomposition of C–C fatty chains. The second weight loss begins at about 340 ℃, which may be due to the thermal decomposition of benzene rings. The weight loss rate reaches 98.33 % at 600 ℃. For rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd, the weight loss starts at about 260 ℃, and the weight loss continues to more than 400 ℃ until the weight loss rate reaches 16.78 % at 600. This weight loss is obviously caused by the thermal decomposition of organic ligands grafted on the surface of rGO. After removing the weight loss of rGO itself, the actual weight loss of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd is 13.45 %, which is the percentage of organic ligands grafted onto the surface of rGO. As we know, TG analysis results are not accurate enough in determining the load of a supported catalyst. Therefore, the determination by ICP-MS was carried out. The results are shown in Table 1. Since each molecule of organic ligand contains one phosphorus element, the ligand content (in mmol/g) of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd is equal to its phosphorus content (in mmol/g). Considering the molecular weight of ligand 8 C-TPPO, the percentage content of loaded ligand is converted according to the formula C L ( % ) = C P × 10 − 3 × M r × 100 , Where, CL is the percentage of ligand on rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd; CP is the phosphorus content, in mmol/g; Mr is the molecular weight of ligand, 511.59 g/mol. The result is also shown in Table 1. 3.4 Morphology and Elemental Distribution of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd Fig. 9 shows the SEM image and EDS mappings of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd. As shown in the SEM image, rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd basically presents the morphology of its carrier, rGO, which is a layered superposition structure. The EDS mappings of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd show that the surface of rGO contains a large amount of phosphorus and palladium, which are evenly distributed. The results reveal that the organic ligand 8 C-TPPO has indeed been evenly grafted onto the surface of rGO, and the rGO-supported catalyst rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd has been successfully prepared. 3.5 Catalytic activities of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd in Suzuki-Miyaura coupling reactions In order to reasonably evaluate the catalytic activity of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd in Suzuki-Miyaura (S-M) cross-coupling reaction, the reaction conditions need to be optimized first. Usually, S-M cross-coupling reaction catalyzed by a homogeneous catalyst needs to be carried out in an anhydrous and oxygen-free reaction environment [41]. However, we hope that with the participation of catalyst rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd, the target product can be obtained only under simple and environment-friendly reaction conditions. Therefore, the solvents were screened first, and several common organic solvents were selected as the reaction solvents, such as N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), THF, toluene, ethanol (EtOH), etc. In a model reaction of synthesizing 4-methylbiphenyl (4-MBP) with iodobenzene and p-tolylboronic acid as substrates and with potassium carbonate as the base, the solvent screening tests were carried out. The results are summarized in Table 2. It can be seen from Table 2 that when the solvents were DMF, THF and toluene respectively, the yields of product 4-MBP were less than 50 % (Table 2 , entry 1–3); When EtOH was used as the solvent, the yield was 59 % (entry 4). However, when pure water was used as the solvent, the yield of the product was only 20 % (entry 5). Therefore, we tried to add ethanol to the aqueous system to form an ethanol/water mixed solvent [42]. The results showed that the addition of ethanol can significantly improve reaction efficiency. By continuously adjusting the ratio of ethanol to water, it was determined that when the ratio of ethanol to water was 3:2, the yield reached 88 % (entry 8). It is considered that the catalytic efficiency of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd is much related to its own structural characteristics. Because organopalladium complexes are connected with rGO through (CH2)8 flexible chain, it can only stretch and diffuse freely in an appropriate solvent, so as to improve the contact frequency between substrate molecules and catalytic active centers. Alkali is another important factor affecting the efficiency of S-M cross-coupling reactions. Several different types of organic bases and inorganic bases were selected for comparative tests. The results showed that when two organic bases triethylamine (TEA) and tetramethylethylenediamine (TMEDA) were used respectively, the yields of 4-MBP were less than 70 % (Table 2 , entry 14–15). However, under the same conditions, when the inorganic bases like K2CO3, KF, Cs2CO3 and K3PO4 were used respectively, the yields of 4-MBP were higher than 80 %, among which K3PO4 had the highest yield (98 %). The turnover frequency (TOF) could be up to 4900 h− 1 under mild conditions in the air. The performance of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd was compared with some solid palladium catalysts and commercial palladium catalysts reported in the literature (see Supporting Information, Table S1). Under the optimized S-M coupling reaction conditions, 20 aryl halides ( Tables 3 , a1-a20) with different structures were selected to react with p-tolylboronic acid (b) respectively. The catalytic activity and substrate adaptability of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd were evaluated by the yield of the products. The results are summarized in Table 3. Firstly, the reaction activities of aryl chloride, aryl bromide and aryl iodide are investigated. It can be seen from Table 3 that the S-M coupling reaction yields of these three types of aryl halides are all higher than 80 %, and the reaction activity order is aryl iodide (a2-I) > aryl bromide (a2-Br) > aryl chloride (a2-Cl), which is obviously related to the dissociation energy of C–X bond [43,44]. Secondly, the reactions between a series of ortho-substituted aryl bromides (a6, a9, a10, a12, a16) with p-tolylboronic acid were investigated. When phenyl or tertiary butyl substituents were in the ortho-position of a benzene ring, the yield of diaryl products would decrease slightly due to the existence of the steric hindrance effect (a6, a9), nevertheless, the yields of coupling products were all at a medium or excellent level. Thirdly, the electronic effect of the substrate on the reaction efficiency was also investigated. The results showed that most aryl bromide (a6-a11) or iodide (a2, a3) with electron-donating substituents in the ortho- or para-position showed good reactivity. For example, when the methoxy group appears at the ortho- or para-substitution position (a10, a11) of the benzene ring, the product yields are higher than 80 %. The yield of diaryl compounds of aryl bromide with electron-donating groups (a2, a3, a6-a11) is slightly higher than that of aryl bromide with electron-withdrawing groups (a4, a5, a12-a17). In addition, the yield of diaryl compounds (a16(2)) increased slightly after increasing the reaction temperature. As we know, most diaryls containing heterocyclic aromatics are important pharmaceutical intermediates. It will be of great significance if they can be obtained by S-M cross-coupling reaction catalyzed by rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd under mild conditions. This was explored in this paper. The results showed that rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd had general adaptability to thiazole, furan and quinazoline heterocyclic substrates, and the product yields were all more than 80 %. It was found that the reaction activity of tolylbonoric acid was slightly higher than that of pinacol ester. In a scale-up test, with 20 mmol iodobenzene as the reaction substrate, the product yield can still reach 90 % under the same reaction conditions, indicating the possibility of the practical application of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd catalyst. The recycling performance of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd was investigated. In an S-M cross-coupling reaction, iodobenzene and p-tolylboronic acid were used as substrates, potassium phosphate as base and ethanol/water (3:2) as solvent, and the yield of the product was determined by HPLC after 2 h reaction. After each cycle reaction, the catalyst was recovered by filtration and washing and used for the next cycle, which goes through 10 cycles. It can be seen from Fig. 10 that although the catalytic efficiency of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd decreased after each recycling, it was not obvious. Even when it was recycled for the tenth time, the product yield decreased by only 10.4 %. The results show that rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd has high catalytic stability and recycling performance. The ICP-MS was used to determine Pd content of the recycled catalyst ( Table 4) and each washing solution. The results showed that the Pd content of each recovered catalyst decreased only slightly and little Pd element was detected in each washing solution, indicating that there was little Pd falling off from rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd after repeated recycling. This is also proved by the hot filtration test (Fig. S31). After 10 min of reaction (yield 46 %), the catalyst was filtered out immediately without cooling the reaction. The reaction of the filtrate lasted for 1 h and the yield was monitored by HPLC (yield 47 %). The yield of the product was hardly improved. This experiment demonstrates that there is little leaching of the active catalytic species in the reaction cycle, or that the leaching is insufficient to show catalytic activity. The results of FTIR, Raman and XPS spectra (Fig. S32-S34) show that after multiple cycles, the chemical composition of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd and active Pd species remain basically stable without obvious covalent bond dissociation. This may be due to the strong carbon-carbon covalent bond between Pd complex and rGO, further proving the high stability and good recycling performance of the catalyst. For mechanism study, Hg poisoning test, XPS and HRTEM analysis have been conducted. The S-M coupling reaction was carried out under the same conditions as in Table 2 with iodobenzene and p-tolylboronic acid as model substrates, and the yield of product was monitored by HPLC. For Hg poisoning test, a drop of Hg was added to the reaction mixture after 10 min of reaction. The HPLC analysis showed that the yield of the product stopped to improve. Therefore, we speculate that the monomeric Pd(0) [45] or Pd(0) nanoparticles [46,47] play a catalytic role. It must be pointed out that these Pd nanoparticles are not leached nanoparticles, but are linked to ligands. Ananikov [48] discussed this issue in depth in their outstanding paper and pointed out that metal complexes may be poisoned by mercury. This was further confirmed by XPS and HRTEM characterization. The XPS spectrum (Fig. S34) of Pd 3d displays a Pd 3d5/2 peak at 335.7 eV and a Pd 3d3/2 peak at 340.9 eV, which correspond to the bonding energies of Pd(0) species [49], meaning the Pd species on the surface of rGO were mainly Pd(0). HRTEM observation (Fig. S35) showed that Pd nanoparticles were present in the catalyst before or after recycling, further confirming that Pd(0) was an active catalytic species. 4 Conclusions In this paper, a novel catalyst rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd was prepared by covalently fixing organopalladium complexes with long and flexible chains on the surface of rGO. The results revealed that rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd showed high catalytic activity in S-M coupling reaction, and can be recovered and reused via simple filtration. Even if the catalyst was recycled 10 times, it can still maintain high catalytic activity. Because the Pd-complex was anchored to the surface of rGO through carbon-carbon covalent bonding, rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd showed high structural stability even in a strongly alkaline reaction medium, ensuring continuous and stable catalytic activity. It had excellent catalytic activity for various substrates with different substituent groups or different substitution positions, showing high substrate adaptability. Since the Pd-complexes are connected with rGO through long and flexible chains, the active centers of rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd can be freely diffused and extended in an appropriate solvent, thereby improving the contact frequency between the substrate and the active centers of the catalyst and obtaining high-efficiency catalytic performance. This paper reveals an effective strategy for the design and synthesis of stable S-M coupling catalyst, which provides a new clue for the development of new efficient and recyclable catalysts. coredata.dc:description: A novel Suzuki-Miyaura (S-M) cross-coupling catalyst (rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd) was prepared by grafting organopalladium complexes with long and flexible chains onto the surface of reduced graphene oxide (rGO) by carbon-carbon covalent bonding. The catalyst was characterized by FTIR, Raman, UV-Vis, TGA, SEM and nitrogen adsorption techniques, respectively. rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd has been used in a variety of S-M coupling reactions. The results showed that it had excellent catalytic activity for various substrates with different substituent groups or substituent positions in ethanol/water mixed solvent at room temperature. Under the optimized reaction conditions, the coupling reaction yield of 4-methyl biphenyl was more than 98 % with iodobenzene and p-tolylbonoric acid as substrates. Even if rGO-8 C-TPP-Pd was recycled for 10 times, the product yield decreased by only 10.4 %, and the chemical structure of the catalyst was basically unchanged. This novel catalytic system provides a new strategy for the design and preparation of supported catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Novel graphene-supported palladium complex catalyst with flexible-bridge-chains and its recycling carbon-carbon cross-coupling activity
